normal_class.name: Normal class
normal_class.comment: There are three ways of setting class in R: S3, S4, and Reference. The S3 class is the original implementation; S3 has no formal definition of a class, rather class is an attribute of an object. The other two are more similar to classes in some other OO languages.

interface.name: Interface
interface.comment: you would need to declare functions to serve as an interface because R is interpreted and not compiled.

private_variables.name: Defining private variables
private_variables.comment: R determines variables by environment, so a variable defined inside of a function is always private to that function and can not be used outside of it.

private_functions.name: Defining private functions
private_functions.comment: In a package, any function not exported is a treated as a private function and cannot be called.

public_functions.name: Defining public functions
public_functions.comment: R functions implicitly return the last call not assigned to a variable in the function or can have an explicitly returned or invisible item.

extends_class.name: Class that inherits/extends another class
extends_class.comment: No S3 implementation. Code shows S4 implementation and reference. For Reference classes, you can use contains to inherit the parent.

calling_superclass_functions.name: Calling a superclass function
calling_superclass_functions.comment: callSuper is only available for Reference classes - only works within a method, and will be resolved to call the inherited method of the same name

overriding_superclass_functions.name: Overriding a superclass function
overriding_superclass_functions.comment: Define the same method in your class.

instantiating_object.name: Instantiating a new object
code: objectname <- 5 # instantiates objectname with a value of 5
instantiating_object.comment:
everything is an object. objects default to a class by their value.
 Objects can be explictly assigned to classes at the time they are instantiated
